fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.retry

Class RetryBuilder<P>

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sii.ogham.core.fluent.AbstractParent<P>
      • fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.retry.RetryBuilder<P>
  • Type Parameters:
    P - the type of the parent builder (when calling AbstractParent.and() method)
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Builder<RetryExecutor>, Parent<P>

    public class RetryBuilder<P>
extends AbstractParent<P>
implements Builder<RetryExecutor>
    Configures retry handling. Ogham provides several strategies to handle retry:
    • FixedDelayRetry: wait for a fixed delay after the last failure
    • FixedIntervalRetry: wait for a fixed delay between executions (do not wait for the end of the action)
    • ExponentialDelayRetry: start with a delay, the next delay will be doubled on so on
    • PerExecutionDelayRetry: provide a custom delay for each execution

    The RetryExecutor instance may be null if nothing has been configured.

    Author:
    Aur√©lien Baudet

    • Constructor Detail

      • RetryBuilder

        public RetryBuilder(P parent,
                    BuildContext buildContext)
        Initializes the builder with a parent builder. The parent builder is used when calling AbstractParent.and() method. The EnvironmentBuilder is used to evaluate properties when build() method is called.
        Parameters:
        parent - the parent builder
        buildContext - for registering instances and property evaluation

    • Method Detail

      • fixedDelay

        public FixedDelayBuilder<RetryBuilder<P>> fixedDelay()
        Retry several times with a fixed delay between each try until the maximum attempts is reached. For example: 
         .fixedDelay()
    .delay(500)
    .maxRetries(5)
        Means that a retry will be attempted every 500ms until 5 attempts are reached (inclusive). For example, you want to connect to an external system at t1=0 and the connection timeout (100ms) is triggered at t2=100ms. Using this retry will provide the following behavior:
        • 0: connect
        • 100: timeout
        • 600: connect
        • 700: timeout
        • 1200: connect
        • 1300: timeout
        • 1800: connect
        • 1900: timeout
        • 2400: connect
        • 2500: timeout
        • 3000: connect
        • 3100: timeout
        • fail
        Returns:
        the builder to configure retry delay and maximum attempts

      • exponentialDelay

        public ExponentialDelayBuilder<RetryBuilder<P>> exponentialDelay()
        Retry several times with a delay that is doubled between each try until the maximum attempts is reached. For example: 
         .exponentialDelay()
    .initialDelay(500)
    .maxRetries(5)
        Means that a retry will be attempted every 500ms until 5 attempts are reached (inclusive). For example, you want to connect to an external system at t1=0 and the connection timeout (100ms) is triggered at t2=100ms. Using this retry will provide the following behavior:
        • 0: connect
        • 100: timeout
        • 600: connect
        • 700: timeout
        • 1700: connect
        • 1800: timeout
        • 3800: connect
        • 3900: timeout
        • 7900: connect
        • 8000: timeout
        • 16000: connect
        • 16100: timeout
        • fail
        Returns:
        the builder to configure initial delay and maximum attempts

      • perExecutionDelay

        public PerExecutionDelayBuilder<RetryBuilder<P>> perExecutionDelay()
        Retry several times with a fixed delay to wait after the last execution failure until the maximum attempts is reached. A specific delay is used for each execution. If there are more attempts than the configured delays, the last delays is used for remaining attempts. For example: 
         .perExecutionDelay()
    .delays(500, 750, 1800)
    .maxRetries(5)
        Means that a retry will be attempted with specified delays until 5 attempts are reached (inclusive). For example, you want to connect to an external system at t1=0 and the connection timeout (100ms) is triggered at t2=100ms. Using this retry will provide the following behavior:
        • 0: connect
        • 100: timeout
        • 600: connect
        • 700: timeout
        • 1450: connect
        • 1550: timeout
        • 3350: connect
        • 3450: timeout
        • 5250: connect
        • 5350: timeout
        • 7150: connect
        • 7250: timeout
        • fail
        Returns:
        the builder to configure retry delay and maximum attempts

      • fixedInterval

        public FixedIntervalBuilder<RetryBuilder<P>> fixedInterval()
        Retry several times with a fixed delay between each try (no matter how long the execution of the action lasts) until the maximum attempts is reached. The next execution date is based on the execution start date of the first execution. For example: 
         .fixedInterval()
    .interval(500)
    .maxRetries(5)
        Means that a retry will be attempted every 500ms until 5 attempts are reached (inclusive). For example, you want to connect to an external system at t1=0 and the connection timeout (100ms) is triggered at t2=100ms. Using this retry will provide the following behavior:
        • 0: connect
        • 100: timeout
        • 500: connect
        • 600: timeout
        • 1000: connect
        • 1100: timeout
        • 1500: connect
        • 1600: timeout
        • 2000: connect
        • 2100: timeout
        • 2500: connect
        • 2600: timeout
        • fail
        NOTE: The provided date doesn't take the duration of the execution in account. If an execution takes 1s to execute while retry delay is set to 500ms, there may have several executions in parallel. However, this totally depends on the RetryExecutor implementation. For example SimpleRetryExecutor won't run several executions in parallel. In this case, it will execute the action as soon as the previous one has failed therefore the delay may not be complied.
        Returns:
        the builder to configure retry delay and maximum attempts

      • awaiter

        public RetryBuilder<P> awaiter(Awaiter impl)
        Change implementation used to wait for some delay between retries. By default, ThreadSleepAwaiter is used (internally uses Thread.sleep(long) to wait for some point in time.
        Parameters:
        impl - the custom implementation
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • executor

        public RetryBuilder<P> executor(RetryExecutor executor)
        Use custom executor instead of default one (SimpleRetryExecutor).

        NOTE: Using custom executor doesn't take retry strategies into account. If you want to benefit from RetryStrategys, use executor(RetryExecutorFactory) instead.

        If executor(RetryExecutorFactory) is also called, only the executor defined by this method is used and the factory is not used.

        If this method is called several times, only the last value is used.

        If you call with null, it removes any previous custom executor.

        Parameters:
        executor - the executor to use
        Returns:
        this builder for fluent chaining

      • executor

        public RetryBuilder<P> executor(RetryExecutorFactory factory)
        Use a factory to create an instance of RetryExecutor while benefiting from configured RetryStrategy.

        The factory will receive the ready to use RetryStrategyProvider and the built Awaiter.

        If executor(RetryExecutor) is also configured, the factory is not used.

        If this method is called several times, only the last factory is used.

        If you call with null, it removes any previous configured factory.

        Parameters:
        factory - the factory used to create the RetryExecutor instance
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • retryable

        public RetryBuilder<P> retryable(Predicate<Throwable> retryable)
        A predicate that checks if the raised error should allow another retry or not. This is useful when an error is raised and the error is severe so it should stop immediately.

        The predicate returns true if the exception is not fatal and a retry may be attempted. It returns false if the exception is fatal and no more attempt should be executed and retry must stop immediately.

        If null is passed to this method, it removes any previously defined predicate. Therefore the default predicate is used: all Exceptions are considered retryable but not Errors.

        Parameters:
        retryable - the predicate that returns true if the exception is not fatal and a retry can be attempted
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • retryable

        public RetryBuilder<P> retryable(UnaryOperator<Predicate<Throwable>> merger)
        Combine the current configured predicate with another.

        This may be useful when an implementation wants to add additional checks to the ones configured by Ogham core or other implementations.

        If no predicate is currently configured, a predicate that accepts everything is provided.

        NOTE: This is advanced usage mostly for developers that extend Ogham with new implementations.

        Parameters:
        merger - a function used to merge predicates
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • retryable

        public RetryBuilder<P> retryable(Condition<Throwable> retryable)
        A condition that checks if the raised error should allow another retry or not. This is useful when an error is raised and the error is severe so it should stop immediately.

        The condition returns true if the exception is not fatal and a retry may be attempted. It returns false if the exception is fatal and no more attempt should be executed and retry must stop immediately.

        If null is passed to this method, it removes any previously defined condition. Therefore the default condition is used: all Exceptions are considered retryable but not Errors.

        This method internally calls retryable(Predicate).

        Parameters:
        retryable - the condition that returns true if the exception is not fatal and a retry can be attempted
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining
